name: Onugbu Soup
description: This is a traditional soup native to the South Easten part of Nigeria
ingredients: A handful of washed and squeezed bitterleaf
3 cooking spoons of Red Palm Oil
Assorted Fish: Stock Fish and Dry Fish
Salt, Pepper and ground crayfish (to taste)
steps_to make: Make sure the bitter leaves are well washed to remove the bitter taste. If the bitterness cannot be completely washed off, boil it for about 15 minutes and wash in cold water
Wash ad cock teh cocoyam till they are soft.Remove the peels and use a mortar and pestle to pound the cocoyams to a smooth paste
Boil the assorted beef, stock fish and dry fish in 1 litre of water till they are well done
Add the 3 stock cubes(Maggi/knorr) and cock for 5 minutes
Add the group crayfish, pepper and bitter leaves and cock for 10 minutes
Add the cocoyam paste in small lumps and the palm oil
Cover the pot and let it cock until the cocoyam lumps have dissolved. You can add water if you feel the soup is too thick
Add salt to taste and cock for a few minutes. The soup is ready

name: Akara
description: Akara is a popular Nigerian food made with beans and it is also known as bean cakes, bean balls or bean fritas. It can be served with pap,custard or fresh bread.
steps: wash the beans thoroughly until the coat comes off and soak in water for 2 hours to make it soft enough to blend
Grind the beans in a blender and make sure to add just a little quantity of water.
Heat up some oil at least 3 inches deep
Empty the ground beans into a deep bowl.
Blend the pepper and onion separately and add it to the ground beans.
mix properly and add one spoonful at a time into the hot oil
Fry until it is brown all over. Remove and place in a sieve lined with paper towels
Repeat this process until the mixture is the bowl is finished
your freshly made hot Akara is ready to be served as desired

name: suya
description: Suya is an infamous spicy delicious street food that we all know and love. It is made either with beef, ram or chicken. Innards like kidney and liver are also used and the dried version of suya is called kilishi. Replicating this delicious goodness is really not a rocket science as the ingredients are readily available and affordable.
steps: soak skewers in water for 12hours so it doesn't burn during grilling
Wash meat thoroughly and slice into thin pieces
Loop the beef onto the skewers
Arrange the skewered meats in a deep dish or tray
Pour vegetable oil in a bowl, add seasoning cube and mix thoroughly
Dip a clean brush into the oil and thoroughly coat the meat with it
Dust the oiled meats with suya spice and make sure it covers the meat properly
Arrange the spice-covered meat on an oven rack and place them in a preheated grill or oven
Set the oven to 200 degrees Celsius and grill each side for 13-15 minutes
Enjoy your delicious homemade suya
